Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             80 
 
Objective:   2.29   Identify the base word, prefix, or suffix in words and the meanings associated with them. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A base word is the simplest form of a 
word. It is also a word to which a prefix 
or suffix can be added to form a new 
word.  
 
Examples: ‘Tell’ and ‘happy’ are words to 
which a prefix and a suffix can be added. 
  
A prefix is a syllable added to the 
beginning of a word that changes the 
word’s meaning. 
 
Prefix Examples:  
‘re’ (prefix) + ‘tell’ (base word) = ‘retell’ 
 
The prefix ‘re’ means ‘again’.  The word 
‘retell’ means to tell again. 
 
‘un’ (prefix) + ‘happy’ (base) = ‘unhappy’ 
  
The prefix ‘un’ means ‘not’.  The word 
‘unhappy’ means not happy. 
 
A suffix is a syllable joined to the end of 
a word that changes its definition. 
 
 
 
Basic:  Write base words with 
prefixes on cards. Cut words 
between the base word and 
the prefix. Give each student a 
card. Have students walk 
around the room and find their 
match / partner. Have partners 
stand together and share their 
word once everyone has 
found his / her match. 
 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
sort words as base words, 
prefixes and suffixes. 
 
Advanced:  Using a 
worksheet, have students 
match prefix and base word 
with their combined meanings.  
They can do the same with 
suffixes. 
Have students create 
words using cards with 
base words, prefixes and 
suffixes. 
  
 Modern 
Curriculum Press 
Phonics B 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             81 
 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Suffix Examples: 
‘Quick’ and ‘care’ are examples of words 
to which a suffix can be added. 
 
The suffix ‘ly’ tells how something is 
being done.   
 
‘quick’ (base word) + ‘ly’ (suffix) = 
‘quickly 
  
This means that something happened 
very fast. 
 
The suffix ‘ful’ can sometimes tell how 
something is being tended to. 
 
‘care’ (base word) + ‘ful’ (suffix) = 
‘careful’ 
 
This means that measures are being 
taken to be safe and to protect. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             82 
 
Objective:   2.30   Add inflectional endings (with or without) spelling changes. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
An inflectional ending is a letter or group 
of letters added to a base word to change 
its meaning. 
-ing 
The ending ‘ing’ tells about something 
that is happening now. 
e.g. The birds are singing. 
  
-ed 
When ‘ed’ is added to the end of a word it 
tells of something that happened in the 
past. 
 e.g. The girl jumped over the rope. 
 
Whenever a short vowel word ends with 
one consonant, the last consonant is 
usually doubled before adding an ending 
that begins with a vowel. (examples: -ed / 
-ing). 
Example: hop 
hopped   hopping 
 
In a one syllable word with a long vowel 
sound and a final ‘e’, the final ‘e’ is 
dropped before adding the ending –ing. 
Examples: 
save  - save - saving 
make – make - making 
Basic:  Distribute cards that 
contain words with inflectional 
endings. Ask students to say 
their word, tell what 
inflectional ending is added 
and what it means. 
  
Intermediate:  Have students 
read a passage with words 
with inflectional endings. Ask 
students to underline the 
words, then, sort words 
underlined using headings: 
Now / Past. 
 
Advanced:  Provide students 
with a list of base words in 
one column and the 
inflectional ending to be 
added in another column.  In 
the third column have 
students combine the two 
using the rules provided, to 
produce the correct spelling.   
Dictate sentences to 
students with words that 
have inflectional endings.  
Assess their spelling of 
these words.  
 Modern 
Curriculum Press 
Phonics B 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             83 
 
SCOPE OF WORK 
FLUENCY 
 
Sub-Goal 2:  Interpret developmentally appropriate printed and audio-visual materials (including literary and 
informational resources) using various comprehension strategies and literary skills. 
 
Objective:   2.34 
 Use visual clues (punctuation marks) to aid reading.  
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested  
Assessment 
Resources 
 
There are specific punctuation marks 
that give cues as to how a particular 
sentence should be read. 
 
Period/Full Stop – Pause and take a 
breath before reading the next 
sentence. 
Example: Today is the first day of 
school.  I just made two new friends. 
 
Comma – Give a slight pause after the 
comma.  Reading too fast or too slowly 
can change the meaning of a sentence. 
Example:. Ms. Smith, my new teacher, 
sent me to the office to get some paper. 
 
Question Mark – Raise your voice at 
the end of a sentence, when there is a 
question mark. This indicates that a 
response may be required. 
Example: Do you like your new school? 
 
Basic:  Using picture cards, 
have students identify the 
common punctuation 
marks/signals and state what 
they mean. 
 
Intermediate:  Provide students 
with sentences.  Model reading 
them aloud for students.  Have 
students take turns reading 
them aloud.  Provide feedback 
on their reading. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
watch clips from newscasts 
where reporters are expressive.  
Discuss their observations.  
Have students pretend that they 
are news reporters and 
conducting readings for “the 
camera”.  Provide feedback.   
Record students 
reading.  Use a rubric to 
evaluate their 
performance. 
 Literacy 
Resource 
Handbook  
      By:  Dr. Ruth 
      Sumner  and 
      Mary Ann  
      Lotmore 
      p. 171-208  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             84 
 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested  
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Exclamation Mark – Read with a 
specific and appropriate emotion, when 
there is an exclamation mark.  
Example: I love my new school and my 
new friends! 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             85 
 
Objective:   2.35 
 Read aloud a variety of texts with appropriate pacing, intonation and expression. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
It is important when reading, to pay 
attention to the rate of speed at which 
you are reading, the rise and fall of your 
voice and expression. 
 
Pace – Refers to how fast or how 
slowly someone is speaking.  Be 
careful not to speak so slowly that 
listeners lose interest. Do not read too 
quickly, otherwise the words may not 
be clear and the listeners may find it 
difficult to follow. 
 
Intonation – The rise and fall of the 
voice to reflect what is happening in the 
reading piece. 
 
Vocal Expression – The tone of the 
reader should reflect the mood of the 
piece.  
Examples: 
Sad Mood - Read slowly, lower the 
voice. 
Angry Mood – Loud, booming voice 
Happy Mood – Light, medium fast voice  
 
Pitch of Voice - Refers to the loudness 
or softness of the voice. 
Basic:   Have students listen to 
a radio drama.  Have them 
discuss the pace, intonations 
and vocal expressions utilized 
by the actors. 
 
Intermediate:  Provide 
students with the same 
sentence to read.  Place 
different emotions on slips of 
paper in a bag.  Have students 
take turns selecting a slip.  
Have them read the line in such 
a way as to portray that 
emotion.  They should use 
intonations, variations in pace 
and expression to capture the 
mood.  Have students identify 
the mood that is being 
portrayed. 
 
Advanced:  Have students take 
turns reading a passage.  
Remind them to pay attention to 
the pacing and their 
expressions.  Allow students to 
give feedback on their reading. 
Have students complete a 
fluency assessment.  Use 
a rubric to score their 
efforts.  
 Literacy 
Resource 
Handbook  
      by:  Dr. Ruth  
      Sumner and  
      Mary Ann  
      Lotmore 
      p. 171-208  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             86 
 
SCOPE OF WORK 
COMPREHENSION 
 
Sub-Goal 2:  Interpret developmentally appropriate printed and audio-visual materials (including literary and 
informational resources) using various comprehension strategies and literary skills. 
 
Objective:   2.36 
 Use different texts and graphic features to assist in understanding written texts. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When reading, track print from left to 
right and top to bottom on page.  Books 
are read from front to back.   
 
There are many ways in which authors 
help readers to understand what they 
are reading.  They are called text 
features. 
 
Book Text Features  
 
Book Cover - Gives the name or title of 
the book, a picture about the book and 
the author(s). 
 
Spine – Holds the pages of a book 
together 
 
Title Page- Gives the title, author(s), 
illustrator(s) and the date the book was 
published.    
Basic: Using actual books, 
have students show the 
different text features identified. 
 
Intermediate: Using copies of 
the same book, have students 
use the Table of Contents to 
help them find certain bits of 
information to answer a 
question.   
 
Advanced:  Have students use 
the glossary to locate specified 
words.   
 
On-line: Have students hover 
over unfamiliar words in an 
eBook to see their meanings. 
Have students complete 
live worksheets where 
they have to use various 
text features to locate 
information.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             87 
 
Content

Activities 
Suggested

Resources 
 
Title – identifies the topic and tells what 
the book or story will be about.  
  
Table of Contents  –  Tells page 
number on which certain topics can be 
found.  It is located at the beginning of 
the book.  
 
Bold – Important words are placed in 
darker print than the rest of the text.  
 
Underlined  –  Key words have a line 
drawn underneath to identify their 
importance. 
 
Highlighted – Words are emphasized 
with a fluorescent colour. 
 
Illustrations  –  Pictures drawn by an 
artist that show what something looks 
like  
 
Photographs – Pictures taken with a 
camera by a photographer 
 
Glossary – Gives the meaning of 
unfamiliar words

Activities

Digital Text Features 
 
Back Button – Press it to go back to 
the last page visited. 
 
Audio – Click on the speaker icon or 
press play to listen to information. 
 
Video – Click on the play icon to view a 
video. 
 
Photographs – Press on the photo

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             89 
 
Objective:   2.38 
 Identify elements of a story (characters, setting, theme(s) and plot. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
In order to make stories interesting, 
authors include characters, setting, 
plot and a theme.  These are 
called story elements. 
 
Character: The people or animals 
in a story are the characters. 
Stories can tell what characters 
look like, what they think, how they 
feel and what they say and do. 
 
Setting: Where a story takes place 
and the time of day that it takes 
place, is called the setting. The 
setting can be a real or a make-
believe place. 
  
Plot: The plot has a beginning, 
middle, and end. It is usually made 
up of the most important events of 
the story. Short stories usually 
have one plot or event. 
 
Theme(s): The theme is the main 
message. 
Basic:  Select students to act as 
characters for an interview during a talk 
show. The host of the talk show can ask 
the characters questions such as:  
1. Who are you?     
2. What did you do? 
3. Where were you when you did it? 
4. What were some of the important things that  
    happened? 
  
Intermediate:  Have students read a text 
at the appropriate reading level.  
Construct a visual diagram and have 
students record the elements of the story 
on the diagram in a group, in pairs or 
individually. 
 Who?    Did What?   When?  
 Where?   How?       Why? 
  
Advanced: Have students work in pairs 
to identify the elements of a story. 
Setting: Tell where the story takes place. 
Character(s): Tell the names of the 
characters and if they are good, bad, 
helpful, mean, funny, etc. 
Problem: Tell what the problem is. 
Solution: Tell how the problem was 
solved. 
 
Read a story and 
have students 
identify the various 
story elements.  
 Literacy 
Resource 
Handbook  
      by:  Dr. Ruth  
      Sumner and  
      Mary Ann  
      Lotmore 
      p. 233-244  
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             90 
 
Objective:   2:39 
 Use context clues to determine the meanings of unfamiliar words. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Context clues help the reader figure out 
the meaning of unfamiliar words while 
reading. Context clues may be in the 
same sentence as the unknown words.  
There are several ways to figure out 
their meanings. 
 
1. Examples – Clues about the 
meanings of words can be found in 
the examples that are given 
following the unfamiliar words. The 
word is often followed by “like” or 
“such as”.   
Example:  Insects, like ants or flies, 
                 like to be near food.  
 
2. Synonyms – Sometimes authors 
use words that are similar in 
meaning to the unfamiliar words to 
explain them. 
      Example:  The dense fog was thick  
                       and heavy. 
 
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students read 
rebus sentences where 
examples and synonym clues 
are provided. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
read sentences where example 
clues are given.  Have them 
use this information to explain 
the meanings of the words. 
 
Advanced: Have students read 
sentences that utilize examples 
and synonyms as context clues.  
Have them use these clues to 
explain the meanings of the 
words. 
 
Have students complete a 
worksheet where they 
have to use the clues 
provided in order to 
understand the meaning 
of unfamiliar words.

ube.com/watch?

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             91 
 
Objective:   2.40 
  Apply knowledge of classification to locate information or items. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Classifying involves grouping 
things that are alike together.   
 
The groupings can be used to 
help us locate items or 
information easily. 
 
 
Basic:  Have students group foods 
based on their food groups.   
 
Intermediate:  Show students 
different aisles in the food store.  
Have them indicate which aisle they 
would go through to locate certain 
food items. 
 
Advanced:  Provide students with a 
child-friendly menu.  Have them use it 
to locate information so that they can 
order appetizers, main courses, 
beverages and desserts.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students locate 
information or an item 
based on the way in 
which it is grouped or 
organized.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             92 
 
Objective:   2.41 
 Make predictions. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When making predictions, think about 
clues the author has given, along with 
what you already know, to make a good 
guess as to what will happen next.  
Predictions may change as new 
information is provided. 
 
 
Basic:  Show pictures of a child 
doing something naughty like 
walking in puddles with his 
good shoes.  Have students 
predict what will happen when 
the child gets home.  Have 
students give reasons for their 
responses.  Relate this to 
making predictions when we 
read. 
 
Intermediate:  After looking at 
the title and illustration on the 
cover of a book, have students 
take a quick picture walk 
through the book.  Ask them to 
make their predictions as to 
what the book will be about. 
 
Advanced:  Begin reading a 
story that is appropriate for 
making predictions.  Stop at 
certain points along the way.  
Have students make predictions 
as to what will happen next.  
Have them give reasons for 
their predictions. 
 
 
Have students make 
predictions as they read.  
Have them provide 
reasons for their 
predictions.  Read on to 
confirm whether or not 
their predictions were 
correct.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             93 
 
Objective:   2.42 
 Derive from text the main idea and supporting details. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
The main idea of a paragraph is the 
one idea to which all the other 
sentences in that paragraph are 
related.  Having a main idea helps 
to keep the paragraph organized. 
The sentences which tell about the 
main idea are called detail 
sentences. 
 
Basic:  Explain to students that at 
home, at school or in an office, 
properly kept files help to keep 
things organized.  Tell them that 
they are going to help you file 
things away.  Give students the 
names of five (5) folders. For 
example, My Family, School, 
Recipes.  etc. Have students place 
items in the correct folders. Relate 
this to the function of the Main Idea 
in a paragraph. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students work 
in groups to construct a mobile. 
Have them cut out a cloud and 
raindrops from a template.  Have 
them write the topic sentence on 
the cloud and supporting details on 
each rain drop.   
 
Advanced:  Divide students into 
four teams. Give each team a set of 
sentence strips with supporting 
details and a main idea that are not 
connected.  The first person in each 
team should tape the main idea 
Present students with a 
paragraph.  Have them 
locate the main idea 
and supporting details.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             95 
 
Objective:   2.43 
 Recall events using the correct sequence. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When reading or writing paragraphs 
and stories, events must be placed 
in the correct order to understand 
what is being read.   We refer to this 
as the sequence of events. 
  
The sequence of events is also 
important when following directions.  
When we follow a recipe, for 
example, we need to follow the steps 
so that the item we are making is 
done correctly. 
  
Clue words such as first, next, 
then, after that, and last help the 
reader to understand the order in 
which certain events happened.   
  
Words such as morning, night and 
evening also tell the order in which 
events happened. 
Basic:  Place sentences from a nursery 
rhyme on sentence strips.  Have 
students place them in the correct 
order. 
  
Intermediate:  Gather comic strips from 
a newspaper. Cut them apart.  Glue the 
separate panels on a stiffer piece of 
paper, then laminate.  
(Put the correct number on the back of 
each piece to show sequence.)  
Have students take turns putting the 
panels in the correct order. 
  
Advanced: Place footprints around the 
classroom at designated spots, for 
example: next to supplies that have 
been knocked off a desk, a desk that 
has been tipped over and next to a book 
in the reading corner.     
Have students follow the footprints and 
observe what took place at each stop. 
Ask students to write about the order in 
which the person moved around the 
classroom, using sequencing words. 
 
 
Have students read a 
simple story.  Have 
students number 
sentences to indicate 
the order in which the 
events took place in 
the story.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             96 
 
Objective:   2.44 
 Distinguish between realism and fantasy/fiction and non-fiction. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Authors sometimes use their 
imaginations to help them write 
interesting stories.  Stories about 
fairies, talking animals and objects 
are not real.  We call these types of 
stories make-believe or fiction. 
  
Books that give us information about 
a person’s life, things that actually 
happened and places that people can 
actually go and visit are considered 
real life or non-fiction. 
 
 
Basic:   Read various scenarios. 
Have the children hold up an ‘M’ 
card for Make-believe and an ‘R’ 
card for Real Life. The teacher 
can ask individual students to 
explain why they held up the 
cards that they did. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
work in pairs or a group to read a 
given passage.  Have them 
determine whether the passage is 
fiction or non-fiction.  Give 
students an opportunity to explain 
their reasoning. 
  
Advanced:  Have students write 
statements that are fiction or non-
fiction.  Place them in a bag.  
Have students take turns 
selecting and reading the 
sentences and determining 
whether they are fiction or non-
fiction. 
 
 
 
Provide students with 
titles to texts of writing.  
Have them determine 
whether they are fiction or 
non-fiction.  
 Library books 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             97 
 
Objective:   2.45 
 Differentiate between fact and opinion. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A fact is a statement that can be proven 
true or false.  This may be done 
through further reading or by asking an 
adult. 
 
Example: 
Christmas Day is on a Monday this 
year. 
 
This is a statement of fact.  It can be 
proven true or false by checking the 
calendar.   
 
An opinion tells how someone thinks or 
feels about a particular topic.  As a 
result, it cannot be proven true or false. 
 
Words that tell how someone feels 
such as thinks or likes, can be used to 
tell opinions.   
 
Example:  Cookies and Cream is the 
best ice cream in the world. 
 
This is an opinion because it expresses 
how this person feels about Cookies 
and Cream ice cream. 
 
Basic: Read a variety of 
sentences. Have the students 
display the ‘F’ card for Fact and 
the ‘O’ card for Opinion. The 
teacher can call on individual 
students to explain why they held 
up the card that they did. 
  
Intermediate:  During guided 
reading, have students go on a 
fact hunt. As they find the facts, 
they can list them on a group 
chart. Each group can then share 
their facts with the class.   
  
Advanced: Have each individual 
select five sentences from a bag 
from the centre of their group.  
Provide them with a Fact and 
Opinion chart. Have them write the 
sentences in the correct column. 
In the third column, ask them to 
explain the reason for their 
answer. 
 
 
Provide students with a 
worksheet where they 
have to determine 
whether or not 
statements are factual 
or statements of 
opinions. 
 Fact and Opinion

Objective:   2.46 
 Summarize and paraphrase texts.  
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When summarizing, give only 
the main idea of a story or 
passage and one or two 
details that will explain what it 
is all about. 
 
 
Basic:   Have students choose a book 
to read.  Ask them to select three (3) 
items that were in the story to help them 
re-tell the story in three sentences.  If 
possible, the items can be physically 
brought to the class so that they can be 
shown while telling the story.    
 
Intermediate:  Have students read a 
story.  Have students list the main 
events from the story.  Provide students 
with a blank story wheel. In one segment

In the remaining segments have them 
use their lists to draw pictures of the 
various scenes in order to tell the story. 
 
Advanced: Provide students with an 
outline of a triangle to help them 
summarize a story. Have students read 
a short story.   In the middle of the 
triangle have them write who the story is 
about.  On one of the sides have them 
write the problem in the story. On the 
second side have them write how the 
problem was solved.  On the third side 
they can include the moral of the story. 
Have students complete 
graphic organizers to 
assist them with 
summarizing a story.

Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When you tell how two or more things 
are alike or the same, you are 
comparing.  
  
Example:  
The truck and the car are red. 
  
When you tell how two things are 
different, you are contrasting. 
  
Example: 
DeAngelo likes to play basketball, but 
Shavado likes to play soccer. 
  
The words different, but, and unlike, 
tell how things are not the same. 
 
 
Basic:  Select two students.  
Have the class identify how they 
are similar and how they are 
different.  
 
Intermediate:  Pair students.   
Provide them with two objects.  
Have them write words to say 
how each item is different from 
the other as well as words to say 
how they are alike.  Display two 
hula hoops in the form of a Venn 
diagram on the floor.  Have 
students take turns placing their 
word cards in the correct parts of 
the hula hoop, telling how the 
items are alike and how they are 
different. 
   
Advanced:  Have students 
compare and contrast two 
characters in a fairy tale or 
nursery rhyme. 
 
 
 
Have students 
compare and contrast 
two characters in a 
story.

Contrasting

When making inferences, use the

Objective:   2.49 
  Identify cause and effect.  
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
One thing may make another thing 
happen.  The reason why it happened 
is called the cause. The words 
because and since may be used to 
signal a cause. What happened is 
called the effect. The words therefore 
and as a result may be used to signal 
an effect.   
 
Basic:  Give students five 
picture cards showing cause 
and effect. Have them play a 
concentration game in which 
they match the cause to the 
correct effect. 
 
Intermediate: Have students 
find the cause and effect 
relationships in popular nursery 
rhymes like Little Miss Muffet. 
  
Advanced: Read a nonfiction 
text and with the assistance of 
the students, write the causes 
of a particular problem and 
effect on a fishbone Graphic 
Organizer. The effects will be 
written on the backbone while 
the causes will be written on the 
bones branching out from the 
backbone. 
 
 
 
 
On a worksheet, have 
students match causes 
and effects.

Authors write for many reasons.

topic. Example: Instructions on how

Advanced:  Have students

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             103 
 
Objective:   2.52 
  Draw conclusions.  
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Authors do not always tell everything in 
a story or in an article.  However, the 
reader can combine several clues 
along with what they already know to 
figure out what is happening. The clues 
may be pictures or words.            
 
 
 
Basic:  Divide students into 
small groups.  Give each group 
a bag.  Each bag should have 
items related to a particular 
sport.  Example: ‘bat’, ‘ball’, 
‘uniform’, etc.  Have students 
use the clues to guess the 
sport.  (If actual items cannot be 
located, pictures can also be 
used.) 
  
Intermediate: Show students a 
short clip from a movie.   Ask 
students to tell what is 
happening based on clues and 
their experiences.  Ask them to 
put the clues and facts together 
to draw a conclusion about the 
clip.    
  
Advanced:  Have students 
read a brief description of an 
unidentified place.  Have them 
use clues to name the location. 
 
 
 
Have students read a 
passage and answer 
questions where they 
have to draw 
conclusions.

Making judgments means using the 
facts provided and our own

right/wrong, good/bad,

Advanced:  Have students listen 
to a simplified version of the

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             105 
 
Objective:   2.54 
 Explain commonly used proverbs.  
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A proverb is a common saying or 
phrase that is used to give advice or 
explain what is believed to be true, 
based on experience.  Some common 
proverbs are: 
 
Actions speak louder than words. 
People watch what we do more than 
listen to what we say.   
 
Idle hands are the Devil’s workshop. 
If we do not keep ourselves busy, then 
we might easily get into trouble. 
 
A stitch in time saves nine. 
We should deal with problems and 
issues right away so that they do not 
build up and become difficult to handle. 
 
Don’t judge a book by its cover. 
Some books may not have a very 
appealing cover but they can still be 
very interesting.  Sometimes we miss 
out on knowing people and 
opportunities because they may not 
appear to be interesting at first.  We 
should avoid doing this. 
 
 
Basic:  Have students discuss an 
event that happened in their lives 
when one of the proverbs might 
have applied. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
match the proverbs with certain 
fairy tales or other stories. 
 
Advanced:  Have students read 
Aesop’s Fables and discuss the 
meaning of the proverbs.  Have 
them identify other stories to which 
the proverbs might apply. 
 
Have students match 
specific proverbs with 
situations presented.  
Have them explain why 
they paired the two. 
 First Aid in 
English 
by:  Angus 
Maciver       p. 
108-110

Every country has its own unique way

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             109 
 
Objective:   3.08 
 Write 0-9 D’Nealian numbers correctly. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Several strokes and patterns are used 
in forming numerals.  Numerals should 
be written on two lines, like the letter 
formations. Below are the guidelines for 
helping to write numerals.  
 
1: top start; slant down 
2: start below the top; curve up, around; slant  
    down left; and over right. 
3: start below the top; curve up, and around  
    halfway; around again, up, and stop. 
4: top start; down halfway; over right. Another  
    top start, to the right; slant down, and  
    through.  
5: top start; over left; slant down halfway; curve 
    around, down, up and stop. 
6: top start; slant down, and curve around; up;  
    and close. 
7: top start; over right; slant down left, 
8: start below the top; curve up, around, down;  
    a snake tail; slant up right; through; and  
    touch 
9: top start; curve down, around, close; slant  
    down.  
10: top start; slant down. Another top start to  
      the right; curve left and down, around, and 
      close.    
 
Basic:  Using crayons/colouring 
pencils, have students rainbow 
write numerals 0 –20 using two 
lined manuscript paper.  
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
write numbers in a series using 
two lines on manuscript paper.  
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write numbers 0 - 50 using two 
lines in exercise books.  
On college ruled folder 
sheets, have students 
write numerals to match 
number words'.  
 Teacher Edition 
D’Nealian 
Handwriting 
Book Grade 1, 
      p. 27 - 38 
 
Instructional 
video: 
https://www.yout
ube.com/watch?
v=S-CwvJZ5Niw

                                 writing.

 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment

Forming and writing lower- and 
upper-case letters begins with 
strokes and stroke patterns.  
 
Each letter has a starting point and 
an ending point. The letters should 
be of the same height and size.  
 
Letters: Mm, Ss, Tt  
- 
Aa, Pp 
- 
Nn, Cc, Ff 
- 
Dd, Rr, Ll 
- 
Oo, Kk 
- 
Bb, Gg, Ww 
- 
Ee, Xx 
- 
Vv, Jj, Qq 
- 
Uu, Yy, 
- 
Zz 
Basic: Have students practice 
writing individual names, special 
names of days of the week or 
places in order to practise the 
formation of uppercase and 
lowercase letters in two lines.  
Remind them of the starting points 
of each letter as well as their 
height and size. 
  
Intermediate:  Using folder sheet 
paper (college ruled), have 
students use two lines to write the 
random series of words dictated 
by the teacher, while appropriately 
sizing all letters. 
  
Advanced:  Using graph paper 
(one inch), have students write 
uppercase letters, using two 
squares (top and bottom) and one

In exercise books,

feedback on their 
writing.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             111 
 
Objective:   3.12 
 Copy and write sentences, paragraphs, letters, invitations and messages with appropriate 
                                  structure etc. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Being able to copy information from a 
whiteboard/chalkboard or book is 
important.  
 
 The eyes and hand need to work 
together to make sure the 
information is properly copied. 
 Letters should be of a good 
reading size.  Avoid making them 
too tiny or too big. 
 Leave a clear space between the 
words so that they are not too 
close together and can easily be 
read. 
 Letters should be properly formed 
and of the same height. 
 Indent when beginning a 
paragraph.  Leave sufficient space 
- about the size of the pinkie finger 
from the margin. 
 Be sure to include the end marks 
after a sentence. 
 
 
Basic: With the use of a Flip 
Chart/Writing Tablet, present a 
passage to students. Have 
students recreate the story in 
the correct sequence, using 
word cards/sentence strips of 
the same passage.  
   
Intermediate: Present students 
with a paragraph written on the 
chalkboard/whiteboard. Have 
students copy passage in 
exercise books. 
  
Advanced: 
Using an LCD projector, present 
a written passage to students 
with spacing, sizing and height 
errors. Have students rewrite 
the passage, including 
corrections. 
 
Use  a checklist to assess 
students’ handwriting. 
 
 Is there a paragraph 
indentation? 
 Are uppercase letters 
correctly positioned and 
formed? 
 Are all lowercase letters 
correctly positioned and 
formed? 
 Is each word 
appropriately spaced? 
 Is each letter 
appropriately sized? 
 Are all words and 
punctuation marks 
correctly placed in the 
passage? 
 D’Nealian 
Handwriting 
Grade 1 
       
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             112 
 
Objective:   3.15 
 Form and write various punctuation marks and symbols. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Punctuation marks are used in writing 
sentences.  
 
Period/Full Stop:  The period/full stop 
is written as a dot placed on top of the 
bottom line at the end of a sentence.  
The dot is made by pressing down with 
the pencil in one spot. 
 
Question Mark:  The question mark is 
written similar to the number 2; start 
below the top line; curve up, around; go 
straight down but not to the bottom line.  
Lift your pencil and move to just on top 
of the bottom line and make a dot. 
(Press down with the pencil in one 
spot.) 
 
Exclamation Mark/Point:  The 
exclamation mark/point is written 
similar to the number 1; start at the top; 
go straight down above the bottom line; 
make a dot on top of the bottom line. 
 
Apostrophe:  The apostrophe is used 
before an ‘s’ to show possession of a  
 
Basic: Present students with a 
group of sentences. Have 
students write the correct 
punctuation marks to complete 
each sentence.  
  
Intermediate: Write dictated 
sentences correctly using the 
correct punctuation marks. 
  
Advanced:  Write dictated 
sentences that include  
apostrophe marks.  
Have students compose a 
paragraph using varied 
types of sentences.  
Checklist:  
-Appropriate spacing 
-Appropriate sizing 
-Correct formation and 
positioning of punctuation 
marks.  
 Teacher Edition 
D’Nealian 
Handwriting 
Level K

Activities

Singular noun.  The apostrophe is also 
used after the ‘s’ to show possession of 
a plural noun.  When writing it, begin 
below the top line with a dot; up, 
around and slant down. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             114 
 
Objective:   3.16 
 Copy and write dates, using abbreviated and full formats. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
The full format of a date includes the 
day, date, month and year.  
 
Example:  Monday, 17th October, 2021 
or Monday, October 17th, 2021 
 
The date in the full format is always 
written using the ordinal number.   
 
Dates can be written in the abbreviated 
format using abbreviations of the day 
and month.  
 
Example:  Mon., 17th Oct., 2021 
 
Basic: Have students write the 
full format of dates for given 
holidays using a calendar.  
  
Intermediate: Write 
abbreviated dates to represent 
date of birth and random dates 
dictated by the teacher.  
  
Advanced: In pairs, have 
students take turns stating 
dates from the calendar.  
Using a coin, have students 
identify if the partner student 
writes the abbreviated or full 
dates stated. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Play a recording of the 
news/ community 
announcements and have 
students write at least 
four dates heard in the 
broadcast, in an 
abbreviated format.

D’Nealian 
Handwriting 
Level K 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             115 
 
SCOPE OF WORK 
GRAMMAR AND USAGE 
 
Sub-Goal 2:  Interpret developmentally appropriate printed and audio-visual materials (including literary and 
informational resources) using various comprehension strategies and literary skills. 
 
 
Objective:   3.17 
 Distinguish between sentences and fragments. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A sentence is a group of words that 
express a complete idea or 
thought.    
Example: We like to play in the 
park.  
 
Sentences should begin with a 
capital letter and end with an end 
mark. There are three different end 
marks: period (.), question mark (?) 
and exclamation point/mark (!). 
 
A fragment is a group of words that 
do not express a complete thought, 
although the first word might be 
capitalized and a punctuation mark 
follows at the end.   
Example: The day he came 
 
Basic:  Have students play the “Jump 
on It” game where they will have to 
differentiate between sentences and 
fragments. Tape/place sentence strips 
or sentence cards throughout the 
classroom and have students, 3 at a 
time, hop on all sentences/fragments. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students work in 
pairs to create simple sentences, 
using word cards and punctuation 
cards. 
 
Advanced: Present students with a 
group of sentences and fragments. 
Have them read each group of words; 
writing “F” (fragment) if the group of 
words is a fragment or “S” if the group 
of words is a sentence. 
 
Present students with 
a list of phrases and 
sentences and ask 
them to categorize 
them as sentences or 
fragments 
 The Grammar 
and Writing Book 
Grade 1,               
Scott Foresman, 
p. 50-53; 208-
209 
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
      p. 352-356 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             116 
 
Objective:   3.18 
 Construct declarative, interrogative, exclamatory and imperative sentences. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
There are four types of sentences.  
A statement, called a telling 
sentence, tells something. The end 
mark used for telling sentences is the 
period/full stop (.). 
Example:  I live in a green house. 
 
A question, called an asking 
sentence, asks something. Questions 
end with a question mark (?).  
Questions usually begin with special 
words such as: would, should, why, 
who, what, when, where, how, is, are 
and will. 
Example:  What is the colour of your 
house? 
 
An exclamatory sentence shows 
strong feelings. It begins with a capital 
letter and ends with an exclamation 
point(!) . 
Example:  Yikes, I lost my homework 
again! 
 
A command sentence gives an order. 
It ends with a period/full stop. 
Example: Give Nate his pencil. 
Basic:  Have students play the 
game, “Tag that Sentence”.  
Read various types of 
sentences and then have 
students raise their hashtag 
cards to indicate the type of 
sentence read.  
Example: Would you be more 
comfortable on the couch? 
  #statement             
#question 
 
Intermediate:  In pairs, have 
students dictate and record 
exclamatory sentences and 
commands about given pictures 
or items.  
                                              
Advanced:  Present students 
with random pictures. Have 
students compose a minimum 
of four sentences for each of 
the two sentence types 
(command and exclamatory). 
Have students complete 
sentences by choosing 
the correct punctuation 
mark.  
 
Sally has a dog (.) 
Is this your book (?) 
Wake up (.) 
Great job (!) 
  
Picture Sentence 
Matching  
 Game for Sentence 
Type 
www.turtlediary.co
m/game/pictures-
the-sentences.html

English Level 2, 
p. 56-61 
 
 The Grammar and 
Writing Book, 
Grade 1, p. 74-77;  
80-83;  84;  200-
203;  204;  206-209 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             117 
 
Objective:   3.19 
 Identify run-on sentences. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A run-on sentence is made up of two 
or more sentences that have been 
joined incorrectly. These types of 
sentences can sometimes go on and 
on.  
 
Example: 
Byron got up late he missed the bus. 
 
Run-on sentences can be corrected 
by placing the conjunction and between 
the sentences. 
 
Byron got up late and he missed the 
bus.  
 
Run-on sentences can also be 
corrected by separating them into two 
different sentences.  
 
Byron got up late. He missed the bus. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students take 
turns picking a sentence from a 
bag. Have them tell if the 
sentence is a run-on sentence. 
 
Intermediate: Using sentence 
strips, have students add 
punctuation marks and capital 
letters in the run-on sentence in 
order to make it two sentences. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
complete a worksheet where 
they will have to correct run-on 
sentences.   
Have students divide run-
on sentences into simple 
sentences by inserting 
periods and capital letters 
at the correct points in the 
run-on sentences. 
 
Houghton Mifflin 
English Level 2, 
p. 309-310 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             118 
 
Objective:   3.20 
 Identify different types of nouns. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Nouns, also called naming words, 
are words that name a person, place, 
animal or thing.  
 
Common nouns do not name a 
particular person, place, animal or 
thing. 
Examples: 
Person:   father 
Place:      island 
Animal:   bird          
Thing:     airplane 
 
Proper nouns name a special 
person, place, animal or thing. Proper 
nouns begin with a capital letter. 
Days of the week, months of the year 
and holidays are proper nouns. 
Examples: 
Person:   Sam Kemp 
Place:      Inagua 
Animal:   Polly          
Thing:     Bahamasair 
 
 
 
 
Basic: Students will play a game 
called Concentration. In this 
game, each student will give a 
noun for the selected category 
when called upon.  
Example: 
Name of a person = Mary 
Name of a place = Nassau  
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
play the game Noun Storm.  
When given a particular letter, 
students will have ten seconds to 
brainstorm as many nouns as 
they can think of that begin with 
that letter.     
 
Advanced:  Students will work in 
groups of four to identify nouns in 
a poem or another kind of writing. 
They will state if they are 
common or proper nouns.   
Have students circle the 
nouns in a given list of 
sentences.  Have 
students determine if the 
circled nouns are 
common or proper nouns.

and Writing Book 
Grade 1,  
Scott Foresman 
p. 86-90;  92-95;  
102;  120    
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             119 
 
Objective:   3.21 
 Form plural nouns with and without spelling changes. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A singular noun names one person, 
place, animal or thing. 
Nouns that name two or more people, 
places, animals or things are called 
plural nouns. 
Some nouns add ‘s’ to name more than 
one.  
 
Add ‘es’ to words that end with: ‘ch’, 
‘sh’, ‘ss’, ‘x’ and  ‘z’ to name more 
than one person, place, animal or thing. 
 
Examples: 
witch       witches 
bush        bushes 
glass       glasses 
box          boxes 
quiz         quizzes 
Basic:  Have students compile 
and illustrate a book that 
contains singular and plural 
nouns.  
  
Intermediate:  Have students 
play the game, “Teacher May 
I?”.  For this game, give 
students different nouns.  Have 
them decide whether to 
add ‘s’ or ‘es’ to the noun to 
form the plural name.  Students 
will then ask, “Teacher may I?”  
Once the teacher says, “Yes, 
you may” students will proceed 
to write the noun on the board 
and add the appropriate 
ending.  
Examples: 
book = books  
fox = foxes.  
  
Advanced:  Have students 
match the singular nouns with 
the correct plural nouns. Have 
students write sentences using 
the plural forms of the nouns.   
 
Have students illustrate 
then write sentences 
about each picture to 
show one or more than 
one.

and Writing Book

Some nouns change their spelling to 
name more than one.  
 
Example: 
I lost a tooth yesterday. 
Billy lost two teeth yesterday. 
 
Other nouns that change spelling to 
name more than one are: 
 
Singular           Plural 
child                  children 
man                  men 
foot                   feet 
goose               geese

forms of the noun on the board.  
 
Advanced: Have students 
choose suitable plural noun 
forms from a word bank, to 
complete a cloze passage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students form 
irregular plurals for given

 Identify compound words.

A compound word is made up of two 
smaller words. Each small word can 
stand alone and have a meaning.

Objective:   3.24 
 Use the correct gender for a noun. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Sometimes there are different words 
that are used to refer to animals that 
are males and animals that are 
females. 
 
Masculine : words denoting male 
creatures (animals)  
Examples:  
bull, gander, boar, fox, lion, ram, 
rooster, stallion, tiger, and drake 
  
Feminine: words denoting female 
creatures (animals)  
Examples:  
cow, goose, sow, vixen, lioness, ewe, 
hen, mare, tigress, and duck 
  
Neutral:  words denoting animals of 
either sex 
Examples:  owl, eagle 
                   it, they, them 
 
 
Basic:  Have students label 
pictures of animal pairs by their 
respective gender 
(male/female) names.  
 
Intermediate: Using a 
farm/pride/forest layout with 
random animal pictures, have 
students name the animals 
presented, giving the names of 
both the male and female.   
 
Advanced: Have students 
select an animal; identify the 
masculine and feminine names 
of the animal; write sentences 
comparing the two.   
Example: A lion has a mane 
and/but the lioness does not. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
After reading a passage 
have students identify 
(circle, underline, mark) 
the masculine or feminine 
names of the animals 
used. Have students write 
the opposite (feminine or 
masculine) animal name 
not presented in the 
passage.  
  
*Have students compile 
the animal names into a 
list. (animal, male, 
female)

Objective:   3.26 
 Form singular and plural possessive nouns. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A possessive noun shows ownership. 
 
Most singular possessive nouns are 
formed by adding an apostrophe (‘) 
and the letter ‘s’ to the noun. 
 
Example: The horse’s tail is black. 
 
If a plural noun ends with the letter ‘s’, 
the possessive noun is formed by 
adding only an apostrophe (‘) after 
the ‘s’. 
 
Example:  These are the girls’ dolls. 
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students pick 
noun cards from the class word 
wall or word box.  Have them 
use the singular noun in a 
sentence to show possession.  
  
Intermediate: Have students 
complete a worksheet where 
they have to write possessive 
nouns for the underlined nouns. 
 
Example: My dentist office has 
a chart on the wall.  
 
Advanced:  Have students 
complete a worksheet, in which 
they will rewrite sentences to 
show the correct form of the 
singular and plural possessive 
nouns. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Present students with a 
list of nouns. Have 
students write the 
singular and plural 
possessive noun for 
each.

English, Level 2

Objective:   3.27 
 Produce the correct pronouns for the nouns they replace. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Pronouns are words that are used 
in place of nouns. The words ‘I’, 
‘you’, ‘he’, ‘she’, ‘they’, ‘we’, ‘our’, 
‘us’, and ‘it’ are examples of 
pronouns. 
 
Example: 
Mary and Jan like ice-cream. 
They like ice-cream. 
The pronoun ‘they’ replaces the 
nouns Mary and Jan. 
 
Use ‘I’ and ‘me’ to talk about 
yourself.  ‘I’ is always capitalized 
when it stands alone as a word.  
When talking about yourself and 
someone else, always say the 
other person’s name first. 
Example: 
Jerry and I are going to the park.  
 
The pronoun ‘me’ is used after an 
action verb. 
Example: 
The lizards jumped on Jan and 
me. 
Basic:  Have students play the I 
Spy game, based on the characters 
of a story/nursery rhyme. 
Example: “I spy with my little eye a 
boy wearing a blue hat.  He has a 
horn. Who is He? 
Answer: Little Boy Blue 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
choose the pronoun from the word 
box for the underlined noun or 
nouns in the sentences. 
 
Steve and Bill made a sand 
castle. 
Word box 
 
 
Answer: They made a sand castle. 
 
Advanced:  Provide students with 
sentences that contain nouns.  Have 
them rewrite the sentences and 
replace the nouns with the 
appropriate pronouns. 
 
 
 
 
Have students rewrite 
common nursery rhymes 
by replacing the nouns 
with pronouns.

English Level 2, 
p. 107-108  
 
 Write Source

by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al

A possessive pronoun replaces a

Some possessive pronouns are

The dog lost its collar

A word that shows action is called a 
verb and is sometimes referred to as 
an action word.  
Examples: jump, jog, hit, swim 
 
Some verbs help the action verb or 
main verb by telling when something 
happened. They are called helping 
verbs.  Helping verbs can be singular 
or plural.

is                          are

am

had

The helping verb ‘have’ is used with the 
pronouns ‘I’, ‘you’, ‘we’ and ‘they’.  
 
Personal Singular 
‘I’  
Use ‘am’ when the subject is ‘I’, in the 
present tense.  
 
Singular Pronouns 
‘he’, ‘she’ and ‘it’  
Use ‘is’ when the subject is a singular

Advanced:  Using strips of paper, 
have students create sentence 
chains/links. Using specific colours,

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             129 
 
Objective:   3.30 
 Apply the correct tenses to verbs. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
There are special ways to say or write 
verbs to tell when something happens.  
For actions that are happening now, the 
present tense is used. For actions that 
have already happened, the past tense 
is used. For actions that are still to 
happen the future tense is used.  
 
Present Tense: 
If the noun is singular (representing one) 
an ‘s’ is added to the verb. 
Example: Ben sings in church.  
When using the pronouns, ‘he’, ‘she’ and 
‘it’, add an ‘s’ to the verb to indicate the 
present tense.  
Example: She jumps into the water. 
 
If the noun is plural, no ‘s’ is added to 
the verb.      
Example: They jump into the water.    
 
Present Tense      
The suffix,‘ing’ can also be added to a 
verb to tell that something is happening 
now.   
Example: Jan is playing in the band. 
 
 
Basic: On the chart provided, fill in 
the missing form of the verb.  
 
Subject 
Present Tense 
Past Tense 
Ryann 
looks 
_______ 
Wendy 
_______ 
jogged 
The 
chicken 
_______ 
crowed 
 
Intermediate: Present students with 
sentence strips and three clothespins 
labelled ‘s’, ‘ed’ and ‘ing’. Have 
students add the appropriate ending 
to the verb in each sentence. 
 
Advanced:  Present students with a 
group of sentences on a worksheet. 
Have students provide the correct 
tense of the verb to make the 
sentence complete. 
 
Example: Sarah ____ through the 
window. 
Verb: jump 
Have students work 
individually to 
complete sentences 
using the correct 
verb tense.

Mifflin English 
Level 2 
p.179-180

Past Tense  
Verbs in the past tense usually end in 
‘ed’. 
Example: Sam jumped on his bike. 
 
Future Tense 
Place the word ‘will’ before the verb to 
show that it will happen in the future. 
Example:  Mr. Smith will wash his car 
tomorrow. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             131 
 
Objective:   3.31 
 Ascertain the complete subject and predicate of a sentence. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A sentence has two parts:  
i. 
the subject, also known as 
the naming part and  
ii. 
the predicate, also known as 
the telling part.  
 
The subject tells who or what the 
sentence is about.   
 
Example:  The playful dog ran all the 
way home. 
  
Who/What ran all the way home?   
the playful dog.   
 
The playful dog is the subject. 
 
The predicate tells what the subject 
does.   
 
The playful dog did what?  Ran all the 
way home 
 
Ran all the way home is the 
predicate.  
  
 
Basic:  Have students listen to 
sentences read, in order to 
identify the naming and telling 
parts of sentences.  
 
Intermediate:  Provide students 
with sentences.  Have them circle 
the naming part of the sentence 
and underline the telling part. 
 
Advanced: Provide students with 
either the naming or telling parts 
of sentences for them to 
complete.  Have them circle the 
naming part and underline the 
telling part in each. 
Having students identify 
the naming and telling 
parts of sentences.

Grade 1 
By:  Kemper, 
Reigel et al         
p. 48-53  
 
 Write Source   
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 354-355 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             132 
 
 
 
Objective:   3.31 
 Identify the simple subject and the simple predicate of a sentence. 
Content 
Suggested 
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
In the naming part of the sentence there 
is one word that is most important.  It is 
the main noun or simple subject. 
 
In the sentence, “The playful dog ran all 
the way home”, The playful dog was 
identified as the naming part or 
complete subject.   
 
What is the main word or most 
important word in the naming part that 
tells what the sentence is about? 
 
‘Dog’ is the main word or simple 
subject. 
 
In the telling part of the sentence, there 
is one word that is most important.  It is 
the main verb or simple predicate.   
 
In the same sentence above, ran all the 
way home was identified as the telling 
part.  What is the main word in the 
telling part that tells what the dog did? 
 
‘Ran’ is the main word or simple 
predicate. 
 
‘Dog ran’ is the simple subject and 
predicate. 
Basic:  Have students listen 
to sentences and identify the 
simple subjects and simple 
predicates. 
 
Intermediate:  Have 
students circle the simple 
subject and underline the 
simple predicate in 
sentences. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write sentences about their 
families.  Have them circle 
the simple subject and 
underline the simple 
predicate. 
Have students identify 
the simple subject and 
simple predicate in 
sentences. 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 354-355

Objective:   3.33 
 Apply the rules of subject-verb ageement. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
The simple subject of a sentence can 
be singular or plural. When it is 
singular, an ‘s’ is added to the verb.  
Example: The bird sings .   
If the subject is plural, then no ‘s’ is 
added to the verb.  
Example: The birds sing. 
 
Basic:  Prepare two bags: one 
with singular and plural nouns 
and the other with singular and 
plural verbs. Have students 
take turns selecting a card from 
each bag. Ask them to discuss 
whether or not the subjects and 
verbs agree. 
              
Intermediate:  Have students 
listen to recorded sentences to 
determine whether or not 
subjects and verbs agree. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write their own subject for the 
given verb, or write their own 
verb for the given subject. 
 
Example: _____ walk the dogs. 
 
The boys walk the dogs. 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students complete 
sentences on worksheets, 
requiring them to make 
subjects and verbs agree.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             134 
 
Objective:   3.35 
 Use adjectives to describe nouns and pronouns. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
An adjective tells more about a noun. 
An adjective is used to describe a 
person, place, thing or animal. 
Adjectives answer the questions, What 
kind? Which one? and How many?  
Adjectives can describe colour, size, 
taste, amount as well as compare 
nouns.  
Some words that tell how many are:  
‘couple’, ‘dozen’, ‘flock’, ‘plenty’, ‘pack’, 
‘twenty’, ‘fifty’, ‘hundred’, ‘thousand’, 
etc.  
 
Some adjectives describe size and 
shape. 
Some words that tell size and shape 
are: ‘medium’, ‘huge’, ‘gigantic’, ‘round’, 
‘flat’, ‘triangular’, etc.  
 
Some adjectives tell how things taste, 
feel, sound and smell 
 
Some sensory words are:  
‘sour’, ‘bitter’, ‘sugary’, ‘smooth’, ‘hard’, 
‘soft’, etc. 
 
Basic:  Have students play the  
I Spy game.  Think of a classroom 
object.  Tell how the object looks 
and feels in a sentence. Class will 
guess the name of the object.   
 
Intermediate: Have students 
identify adjectives in sentences 
provided. 
 
Advanced:  Distribute 
goldfish/animal crackers or have 
students select a snack from their 
bags. Have students examine the 
snack closely. Ask them to: 
1. feel it;  
2. smell it;  
3. taste it;  
4. listen to the sound while 
eating.  
 
Ask students to make a web to 
show sensory adjectives about the 
item.    
 
 
Provide students with 
several nouns.  Have 
them compose 
sentences that contain 
adjectives that 
describe the nouns or 
pronouns.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 346-349 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             135 
 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
‘A’ and ‘an’ are known as articles.  
They come before nouns that name 
one. 
‘A’ comes before a noun that begins 
with a consonant. 
Example: a book 
‘An’ comes before a noun that begins 
with a vowel. 
Example: an exercise book 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             136 
 
Objective:   3.36 
 Use adverbs to modify verbs, adjectives and other adverbs. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested  
Assessment 
Resources 
 
An adverb tells more about a verb. It 
tells how, when and where the action 
happened.                                                 
 
Adverbs tell how: 
Example: We ate quickly. 
 
 
Adverbs tell when: 
Example: They went to church 
yesterday.  
 
Adverbs tell where: 
Example: We played there.  
 
 
More adverbs: 
 
How       When         Where 
softly       always        away 
loudly      today          there 
quickly    often           upstairs 
slowly     tomorrow     here 
 
 
 
 
Basic:  Present students with a 
group of adverbs. Have 
students sort them according to 
the questions that they answer: 
‘how’, ‘where’ and ‘when’.  
 
Intermediate:  Read a group of 
sentences. Have students 
identify the adverb in each 
sentence by circling the adverb 
and labelling it with the letter ‘a’.  
 
Advanced:  Organize students 
into groups of four. Distribute 
four envelopes with word cards 
labelled: ‘noun’, ‘verb’, 
‘adjective’ and ‘adverb’. Have 
students select a random word 
from each envelope to create a 
complete sentence. Each 
sentence must have at least 
one noun, verb, adjective, and 
adverb. 
 
 
 
Students will proofread a 
group of sentences. Have 
students correct or 
improve sentences by 
inserting an adverb that 
best completes each 
sentence. 
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right 
p. 69  
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 474 - 475 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             137 
 
Objective:   3.37 
 Use prepositions to link words in sentences. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A preposition tells the location or 
direction of something. It can also show 
the relationship between words in a 
sentence. 
 
Some prepositions that tell position are:  
 
Examples: 
at, by, to, for, up, in, on, of, over, up, 
under, after, behind,  before, near, off, 
down, with,  across, above, until, 
around, inside, outside 
 
Katie hid behind the tree to avoid the 
dog. 
 
The word ‘behind’ tells us where Katie 
was in relation to the tree. 
Basic:  “Where is the dog?” 
(similar to “Where is Waldo?”). 
Using words from a word bank, 
have students label pictures 
with prepositions to identify the 
position of the dog in each 
picture.  
 
Intermediate: Using pictures, 
have students complete 
sentences using prepositions 
that best describe the location 
of an object in each picture.  
 
Advanced: Present students 
with a list of prepositions. Have 
students compose sentences 
using each of the given 
prepositions. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students provide 
prepositions to complete 
sentences. 
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right,  
p. 74 
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 476-477 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             138 
 
Objective:   3.38 
 Use conjunctions to join words or phrases. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Conjunctions join words or groups of 
words. Some conjunctions are ‘and’, 
‘but’ and ‘or’. 
 
Conjunctions can serve different 
purposes. 
 
Combining Information in Sentences 
Example: John loves conch salad. 
                John loves conch fritters. 
    
John loves conch salad and conch 
fritters. 
 
Don wants to walk to the park. 
Karen wants to walk to the park. 
 
Don and Karen want to walk to the 
park.  
 
Showing Differences 
Example: Simon loves chocolate. 
                Simon hates chocolate ice- 
                cream. 
Simon loves chocolate, but he hates 
chocolate ice cream.  
 
Giving Options 
Example: Do you want turkey or ham? 
 
Basic:  Have students circle 
conjunctions in a short 
passage.   
 
Intermediate: Fill in the blank 
to complete sentences using 
conjunctions from a word box. 
 
Advanced:   Provide students 
with sentence stems.  Have 
students use the appropriate 
conjunction to assist them in 
completing the sentences.  
 
Example: 
Sally likes broccoli, 
________________________ 
 
Sally likes broccoli, but she 
hates corn.   
 
Have students combine 
sentences using the 
appropriate conjunctions. 
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right 
p. 78 
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 476 - 477 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             139 
 
Objective:   3.40 
 Expand simple sentences into compound and complex sentences. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A simple sentence has a subject and 
a verb and expresses a complete 
thought.  
Example: Stan took an apple.  
Two simple sentences can be joined 
to make one complete sentence. These 
simple sentences can be joined using 
the word ‘and’.  
Example: 
Stan took an apple.  
He ate it by the pool. 
 
Stan took an apple and he ate it by the 
pool.  
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students join two 
sentences using the conjunction 
‘and’. 
 
Intermediate:  Have a student 
create a simple sentence.  
Example: The boy ran onto the 
beach.  
 
Have another student expand it 
into a compound sentence. 
Example: The boy ran onto the 
beach and he dashed into the 
water.  
 
Advanced:  Have students play 
a KAHOOT game where they 
must identify simple and 
compound sentences. Ask 
students to justify their 
responses. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students join two 
simple sentences 
together with the 
conjunctions ‘and’, ‘or’, or 
‘but’.  
 
 
 The Grammar 
and Writing 
Book, Grade 2,      
p. 218-221 
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 406 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             140 
 
Objective:   3.41 
 Use interjections in sentences. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
An interjection can be one word 
or a group of words that express 
strong emotions like excitement, 
anger, dismay or surprise.   
 
Some examples of interjections 
are: hey, oh, gee, oops, ouch, 
hooray, and wow                         
 
Interjections are followed by an 
exclamation mark (!). 
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students match the 
pictures of situations or events with 
the correct interjection. 
Examples: 
Picture             Interjection 
hitting toe               Ouch! 
winning a game      Hooray! 
falling glass            Oops! 
 
Intermediate:  Distribute interjection 
word cards to students. Have 
students listen to a passage. As the 
interjection is heard in the story, have 
students holding the interjection word 
card stand and display the word.   
 
Advanced:  Present a cloze 
passage in which students will use 
context clues to select the 
interjection that will best complete 
the passage. 
 
Example: 
 “___! Mr. Rolle’s car is so cool!” 
(Wow) 
 
“___! That cat is scary!” (Yikes) 
 
 
Have students use 
interjections in sentences.  
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right 
p. 81   
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 476-477 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             141 
 
Objective:   3.42 
 Provide synonyms for given words. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Synonyms are words which have the 
same, or nearly the same meaning. 
 
Examples:  
pig/ hog 
close/shut 
look / stare 
happy / glad 
end/ finish 
speak / talk  
clever/smart 
 
Basic: Provide students with 
labelled picture cards. Have 
students identify the names of 
picture cards and then match 
the two cards that are similar in 
meaning and explain their 
reasons for matching. 
 
Intermediate:  Given a list of 
words, have students replace 
the underlined word in the  
sentence with the appropriate 
synonym.   
 
Advanced: Give students a list 
of five words. Have them write 
the synonym for each word. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students rewrite a 
passage where they must 
replace the underlined 
words with synonyms. 
  
 
The Students’ 
Companion     
by:  Wilfred D. 
Best,   
p.146-150 
  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 267 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             142 
 
Objective:   3.43 
 Provide antonyms for given words. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A word meaning the opposite of 
another word is known as an antonym. 
 
Examples: 
least---most 
early---late 
all---none 
best---worst 
rich---poor 
smile---frown 
high---low 
question---answer 
smooth---rough 
 
 
Basic: Have students 
participate in a Simeon Says 
game.  They must do the 
opposite of what the teacher 
commands.   
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
rewrite rebus sentences, 
replacing the underlined 
adjective with its antonym. 
  
Advanced:  Have students cut 
out pictures from magazines or 
download from online to create 
a picture book of opposites.  
Have them label the pictures. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Antonym Word Sort. 
Have students categorize 
a group of words to make 
antonym word pairs. 
  
 
The Students’ 
Companion     
by:  Wilfred D. 
Best 
p. 143-150
