Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             143 
 
Objective:   3.44 
 Differentiate among homonyms, homophones and homographs. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Homophones are words that sound 
the same but have different spellings 
and meanings. 
 
Examples: 
see – sea 
sun – son 
to – two  
for – four 
ate – eight 
know – no 
blew – blue 
deer – dear 
sail – sale 
hear – here 
air - ear 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Basic:  Have students draw 
pictures to represent 
homophone pairs. Label each 
picture.  
 
Intermediate: Have students 
create a book of homophones 
and their definitions. 
 
Advanced: Have students 
complete an activity sheet. Ask 
them to identify the appropriate 
homophone to complete each 
sentence.  
 
 
 
Sentence Repair: Have 
students read each 
sentence and replace the 
incorrect homophone with 
the correct homophone. 
  
 
Illustrated First 
Aid in English, 
p. 73 
 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
      p. 418-447 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             144 
 
Objective:   3.45 
 Apply capitalization rules appropriately. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
The first word in a sentence always 
begins with a capital letter.  
Example: This is my book. 
 
The pronoun “I” is always capitalized.  
Example: Jan and I are friends. 
 
Proper nouns that name a particular 
person, place, thing or animal begin 
with capital letters.  
Examples:  Jan, Eleuthera, Bahamas, 
Rover, Wednesday and Max 
 
Some special names are titles for 
people. These special names and titles 
begin with a capital letter.   
Examples: 
Ms. 
Mr. 
Right Honorable Sir Lynden Pindling 
 
 
Basic:  Have students replace 
proper nouns with common 
nouns.    
Examples:  
street  Bay Street 
island  Andros  
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
read a nursery rhyme or short 
poem with no capitalizations. 
Under each letter that should be 
capitalized, have students draw 
three lines.  
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write a letter to a friend about a 
community helper that visited 
their school.  Tell them to be 
sure to put the helper’s name 
and something they learnt.  
Students will be sure to adhere 
to the capitalization rules. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students find 
examples of titles in 
newspapers, books and 
magazines and set up a 
small display for titles of 
people. 
  
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right 
p. 98 
   
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 418-421 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             145 
 
Objective:   3.47 
 Use acronyms. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Acronyms are words formed using the 
initial letter or letters of a group of 
words in succession to form a  
shortened form of a name. 
 
BTC - Bahamas Telecommunications 
Corporation 
  
BPL - Bahamas Power and Light 
 
RBPF - Royal Bahamas Police Force 
 
DS - District Superintendent 
 
ZNS - Zephyr News Sunshine 
 
PMH - Princess Margaret Hospital 
 
KFC - Kentucky Fried Chicken 
 
PI  - Paradise Island 
 
RBC - Royal Bank of Canada 
 
 
Basic:  Have students search 
various sources for pictures to 
match the list of given 
acronyms.  
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
work in pairs to find at least 10 
acronyms from the newspaper 
or phone books (yellow or white 
pages). 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
complete an activity sheet, 
where they match the acronym 
with its complete name. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students write 
acronyms for a list of titles 
and names.  
 
Checking Your 
Grammar and 
Getting It Right        
p. 136 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             146 
 
SCOPE OF WORK 
COMPOSITION WRITING 
 
Sub-Goal 2:  Interpret developmentally appropriate printed and audio-visual materials (including literary and 
informational resources) using various comprehension strategies and literary skills. 
 
Objective:  3.48 
 Explain the steps in the Writing Process. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
The five steps in the Writing Process are:  
Prewriting- The writer gathers ideas and 
plans. 
 
Writing- The writer records ideas. 
 
Revising- the writer makes changes to 
improve the ideas. 
 
Editing- the writer checks the written 
piece for mistakes. Use proofreading 
marks for: 
 capitalizing a letter, 
 making a capital letter, lowercase 
 adding a period  
 correcting a spelling error 
 taking something out 
 adding a letter or word 
 inserting punctuation marks. 
 
Publishing- the writer shares the text with 
others. 
Basic:   Provide a template of a 
staircase.  Have students label 
each level of the staircase with 
one of the steps in the writing 
process. 
  
Intermediate:   Have students 
match cards labelled with the 
steps in the writing process with  
the most appropriate description 
cards. 
 
Advanced:  Have students use 
the staircase model to explain 
the steps in the writing process. 
Have students place 
the steps in the 
writing process in 
order and explain 
what happens in 
each step.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 6-15 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             147 
 
Objective:   3.49 
 Discuss the qualities of a good writing. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When telling a story, make sure that it 
is interesting to those who will be 
hearing or reading it.  A good story: 
 
1. has great ideas; 
2. has an interesting beginning and  
ending; 
3. is easy to follow; 
4. has action; 
5. has specific details; 
6. has the best words to describe 
what can be seen, heard, felt, 
tasted and smelled to help the 
readers to picture exactly what is 
happening; 
7. has short and long sentences; 
8. follows the writing rules; 
9. engages the readers so that they 
feel like the author is speaking 
directly to them; 
10. includes pictures; and 
11. looks neat and attractive. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Basic: Read a short story to 
students.  Have them talk about 
their favourite parts.  Relate this 
to the qualities of good writing. 
 
Intermediate: Read a short 
story to students and have them 
discuss ways in which they 
could improve it. 
 
Advanced: Have students 
identify two characteristics of 
writing that they think are most 
important.  Ask them to share 
their reasons with the class. 
 
Have students identify 
and explain at least three 
qualities of good writing.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 20-27 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             148 
 
Objective:   3.50 
 Explain the four types of writing. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
There are four reasons why we write: 
 
1. Writing to tell a story – A story can 
tell about what happened to you or 
someone else. 
 
2. Writing to describe – The senses 
are used to tell how something 
looks, feels, tastes, sounds or 
smells. 
 
3. Writing to explain – The writer 
gives information or gives 
directions. 
 
4. Writing to provide an opinion on a  
particular topic. 
 
Basic:  Teach students a song 
about the different types of 
writing that they can easily 
remember. 
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
conduct an interview using 
popsicle puppets that represent 
each type of writing.  Have the 
interviewer ask students 
questions about their particular 
type of writing. 
 
Advanced:  Have students look 
around their classroom for 
examples of the different types 
of writing.   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students use flash 
cards to help them 
explain a particular type 
of writing.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 39, 51, 89, 
127 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             149 
 
Objective:   3.51 Narrow ideas and elaborate on them. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Before beginning to write, it is important 
to stop and get your ideas ready for 
writing.  There are several ways to do 
this. 
 
1. Look at or draw pictures about the 
topic. 
 
2. Think about what you already know 
about the topic and make a list. 
 
3. Talk to someone about the topic. 
 
4. Pick the best ideas about which to 
write. 
 
5. Ask questions such as: Who?  
What?  Where? When? Why? and 
How? to help you write about your 
ideas. 
 
 
Basic:  Show students a picture 
of activities at Fun Day or a 
Fair. After discussing the many 
activities that can happen at a 
fair, have students write about 
one of the activities.  
 
Intermediate:  Have students 
make a list of their favourite 
foods.  Have them select one of 
them to write about how it 
looks, tastes, feels, sounds and 
smells.  Have them write a list 
poem that includes a 
description of their favourite 
food. 
 
Advanced:  Have students talk 
to their classmates about their 
favourite beach activities.  Ask 
them to select one on which to 
write.  Have them describe the 
activity. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Provide students with a 
topic and have them 
narrow the ideas and 
elaborate on them.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
Descriptive 
Writing p. 42, 
Narrative Writing 
p. 54, Expository 
Writing p. 92, 
and Persuasive 
Writing p. 130 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             150 
 
Objective:   3.52 
 Sequence ideas appropriately, using transitional words. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
We can show the order in which 
things happen, happened or will 
happen, by using time-order 
words.  ‘First’, ‘next’, ‘then’, and 
‘last’ are time-order words. You 
can put ideas in order by telling 
what takes place first, next and 
last. 
Example:  
First we all stand at attention.  
Then the Bahamian flag is raised. 
Last we sing the national anthem. 
 
Before Words:  once, not long 
ago, early and yesterday 
 
Words that Show First: 
In the beginning, before, to start 
with 
 
Words that Show Next: 
After, after a while, following, later 
 
Words that Show Last: 
At last, in the end, to finish 
 
 
Basic: Show students large cut-out 
pieces of the ingredients of a 
hamburger sandwich. As a whole class 
activity, have the students correctly 
assemble the hamburger sandwich.  
List the steps taken on the chalkboard 
and number them to show sequential 
order. 
 
Intermediate: Display a picture of a 
hamburger sandwich for all the students 
to see. Provide groups of students with 
sentence strips containing each step of 
making the sandwich.  Challenge 
students to arrange the sentence strips 
in sequential order to show how the 
hamburger sandwich is made. Have 
them circle time order words in each 
sentence. 
 
Advanced: Have students write 
explanations about how to make their 
favourite sandwiches or snack. 
Encourage students to write complete 
sentences and to write and number the 
steps in their explanation in sequential 
order. Compile a class cookbook and 
make a copy for each student. 
 
Have students use 
time order words to 
explain a process. 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 395 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             151 
 
Objective:   3.53 
 Organize ideas into a paragraph, using a topic sentence and supporting details. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
A group of sentences that is used 
to tell about a particular topic or 
subject is called a paragraph.   
 
The sentence that tells the reader 
the topic or focus of the idea being 
expressed throughout the 
paragraph usually comes first.  
This sentence is called the topic 
sentence.  
 
The sentences that provide the 
information about that topic are 
called supporting details.   
 
 
 
Basic: Initiate a whole class discussion 
about flowers.  Using a flower graphic 
organizer, have students record 
thoughts about colour, texture, size, 
scent or aroma; where they normally 
see flowers and how flowers make 
people feel.  Following this pre-writing 
activity, have students create a topic 
sentence and supporting details about 
the subject of flowers.   
 
Intermediate: Provide students with a 
picture of the lignum vitae and the 
yellow elder. Have them consider both 
photos and write a paragraph about one 
of them. Tell students that the topic 
sentence for their paragraph must state 
the flower on which they are focusing.  
The detail sentences must all be related 
to the flower selected. 
 
Advanced: After viewing a video about 
the Blue Marlin. Have students write a 
paragraph with a topic sentence, that 
tells details about the fish. 
 
 
 
Have students write a 
simple paragraph with 
a topic sentence and 
supporting details. 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 41, 43 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             152 
 
Objective:   3.54 Compose varied and interesting introductions to their writing pieces. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When writing, how the story or piece 
begins is very important.  The writer 
should try to grab the attention of the 
person who is reading the piece right 
away. This can be done in several 
ways. 
 
 Begin with a question.  Have you 
ever fallen out of bed? 
 
 Start with lots of action.  Mr. Rolle 
held tightly on to his line.  Suddenly, 
the fish gave a big jerk and pulled 
the line out of Mr. Rolle’s hands. 
 
 Use sound words.  Clip-clop, clip-
clop went the horse as it pulled the 
carriage filled with tourist down 
Shirley Street. 
 
 Begin with words that sound 
alike.  Hungry, hot and hurt, the 
man sat quietly on the rock 
 
 
Basic:  Have students make a 
collection of sound words that 
they can easily access when 
they are writing.  Have them 
draw a picture on one side of 
the card and the word 
representing the sound made, 
on the other side of the card. 
Ask leading questions like, 
“What does the duck say?”  
Have them select an 
appropriate sound word to 
begin a piece of writing.  
 
Intermediate:  Ask students to 
write about the Needs of Living 
Things or another Social 
Science topic.  Have them 
begin the piece with a question. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
watch a movie clip that begins 
with a lot of action.  Have them 
capture the beginning in their 
writing. 
 
Have students write a 
paragraph with an 
interesting introduction.  
Use a rubric to assess. 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 64,102 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             153 
 
Objective:   3.55 Utilize various methods of concluding pieces in their writing. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When writing, it is important to bring the 
pieces to an end.  There are several 
ways to do this. 
 
 Solve the problem. 
 
 Give the lesson that was learned. 
 
 Say what you think. 
 
 End with a hope or a thought. 
 
Basic:  Read Aesop’s Fables 
with the students.  Have them 
discuss the lessons learned.  
Ask them to use one of the 
lessons in a story of their own. 
 
Intermediate:  Provide a story 
for students.  Give three 
possible solutions to the story.  
Have students decide on which 
ending is best.  Discuss 
reasons why.  Have students 
incorporate those elements into 
their conclusions. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write about the recent band on 
using plastic straws and bags.  
Have them give their opinions 
on the band as their conclusion. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students write a 
story and conclude it in 
an interesting way.  Use a 
rubric to assess their 
writing.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             154 
 
Objective:   3.56 
 Demonstrate voice in their writing texts by exploring tone and mood. 
Content 
Suggested 
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
When writing, it is important to 
sound interested in what is being 
written.   
 
Stories should be written like they 
are being told to a friend. Be funny 
if it suits what is being said.  If it is 
something sad being said, use 
words that would make the reader 
feel sad. 
 
Be as detailed as possible.  Be 
sure to use the senses in 
describing people, places and 
things.   
 
Be clear when writing.  Give good 
explanations when sharing the 
steps to complete something. 
 
Give strong reasons to support 
any opinions you are sharing.  
Keep it serious so that the reader 
pays attention to what is being 
said. 
 
 
 
Basic:   Have students sing and 
demonstrate the “Voice Song” (sung 
to the tune of “If You’re Happy and 
You Know It”).  Use the reference 
below or write your own. 
Ruth Culham’s Writing Traits for the 
Classroom K-2 p. 57 
 
Intermediate: Give students a line of 
text to read and a descriptor. Ask 
student to read the line out loud in 
that voice. Let the other students 
guess the voice or a synonym for it.    
 
Advanced:  Have students select an 
emoticon out of a bag.  Have them 
write sentences/paragraph to reflect 
that emotion.  Have them share their 
writing.  Ask the students to 
determine the emoticon that had 
been selected. 
 
Have students complete a 
piece of writing.  Assess it 
using a rubric for the 
Voice trait.  
 6 + 1 Traits of 
Writing K-2,  
      by:  Ruth  
      Culham  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             155 
 
Objective:   3.57 
 Write from different points of view. 
Content 
Suggested Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Many people can tell the same story 
about an experience but it will be 
different for each of them because they 
all looked at what happened in different 
ways. 
 
Use words such as: ‘I’, ‘me’, ‘my’ and 
‘we’ to tell a story about you. 
 
Use words such as: ‘you’ and ‘yours’ to 
tell the story as if someone else is 
watching what happens. 
 
Use ‘he’, ‘she’, ‘it’ and’ they’ when you 
are watching the story unfold. 
 
Sometimes the writer can pretend to be 
an animal or object to tell their side of 
the story. 
 
 
Basic:  Have a student hold a 
camera in front and video tape 
himself walking along the 
sidewalk.  Then have another 
student videotape him walking 
down the same sidewalk.  
Share both views with the class.  
Discuss any similarities and 
differences.  Relate it to writing. 
 
Intermediate:  Read the Seven 
Blind Mice by Ed Young or a 
similar story.  The Mice 
discover something mysterious 
by the pond.  Each feels a 
different part of the object and 
comes up with his own theory 
as to what it is.  Relate this to 
having different viewpoints in 
writing. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
imagine that they are a mango 
tree with lots of mangoes next 
door to a school. Ask them to 
write about the experiences that 
the tree would have. 
 
 
Have students complete a 
piece of writing from a 
specific perspective.  Use 
a rubric to assess their 
writing.  
 6 + 1 Traits of 
Writing,  
      Ruth Culhan,  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             156 
 
Objective:   3.58 
 Compose different types of poetry such as limericks, cinquains, free verse, etc. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Poems are a fun way of expressing our 
ideas and thoughts.  They can come in 
many different forms.  
Rhyming Poems  
In rhyming poems, the words at the end 
of line pairs rhyme. There should be 
about the same number of words in the 
line pairs that rhyme so that the flow of 
the poem is consistent.  
  
Cinquains  
The Cinquain (/ˈsɪŋkeɪn/ is a five-line 
poem. Each line has a specific number 
of words as well as type of words.  
Line One –    1 word (noun)  
Line Two –    2 words (adjectives that   
                      describe the noun in line 1)  
Line Three – 3 words (action)  
Line Four –   4 words (longer description)  
Line Five –    1 word (noun that relates to the  
                      noun in line 1)  
 
List Poems  
List poems are written as lists.  They 
may simply have a list of words or there 
may be a common phrase in each 
line.  All of the lines refer to the person 
or thing that the poem is about.  
 
Basic:  Have students make a 
class poem.  The teacher can 
provide the stem of the poem 
and have students provide the 
rhyming words at the end.  
Intermediate: Provide students 
with stimulating pictures such 
as a delicious chocolate cake or 
an ice cream topped with a 
variety of toppings.  Have 
them write a Cinquain poem 
about the picture.  
Advanced:   Have 
students write a list poem about 
a current Science or Social 
Studies topic.  
 
Have students write a 
poem.  Use a rubric to 
assess.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 253-255, 243-
250 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             157 
 
Objective:   3.60 
 Develop narrative pieces that include characters, setting and plot. 
Content 
Suggested 
 Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Writing stories is a way of telling about 
something that happened.  Stories 
should have a beginning, middle and 
an end.   
 
Stories should tell about animals or 
people that are included in the events. 
These are called story characters.  
What did they say?  How did they look?  
Where did they go? 
 
Stories should also give an idea of 
where the events are happening...in 
school? at the fair? on Crooked Island?  
This is called the setting or the place 
where the stories are taking place. 
 
Stories should give a problem and 
explain how it is solved.  This is called 
the plot. 
 
 
Basic: Have students listen to a 
simple song that tells a story.  
Have them identify the 
characters, setting and plot.   
 
Intermediate:  Ask students to 
write a story about a big 
surprise.  Have students first 
draw pictures of the characters 
in their stories.  Have them use 
details from their pictures to tell 
more about the characters in 
their writing pieces. 
 
Advanced:  Have students look 
at pictures from a magazine, 
calendar or on the internet to 
pick a setting for their stories.  
Let them take a little time to 
write about what it looks like.  
Have them incorporate these 
descriptions in their stories.    
 
 
 
 
 
Have students write a 
narrative piece.  Use a 
rubric to assess.  
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 52-86 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             158 
 
Objective:   3.61 
 Write descriptive essays that utilize interesting words and literary devices (similes,  
                                  metaphors and personification). 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
In descriptive writing it is important to 
describe people, animals, places, 
items etc. in such detail that readers 
can picture them in their minds as 
they read.  
Using the senses to help build 
descriptions is key.  Include what you 
can see, feel, taste, smell or hear.  
Comparing one thing to another is 
another way of helping with 
descriptions.  
Example; The dog’s bark was as 
sharp as a whistle. 
 
 
Basic: Select a simple paragraph 
that is particularly rich in sensory 
detail. Present a copy of the 
paragraph to each child. Read 
through the paragraph together 
and have the students identify 
(circle) the describing words. 
  
Intermediate: Select a simple 
paragraph from a basal reader. 
Create a cloze paragraph by 
adding or leaving blank spaces 
where adjectives were or could be 
added. Have the students read 
and then write their own describing 
words to complete the paragraph. 
  
Advanced:  Give each child a 
paragraph frame with a topic 
sentence describing an animal or 
thing.  Examples: My dog is very 
funny. or Oranges are very juicy. 
Have the students write two or 
three more descriptive sentences 
to support the topic sentence. 
 
 
Have students write a 
descriptive piece.  Use a 
rubric to assess. 
 Write Source,    
Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 40-46 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             159 
 
Objective:   3.62 
 Write expository essays (biographies, how to paragraphs, newspaper articles, reports,  
                                  reviews etc.) 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
In addition to writing stories and 
describing events or people, there is a 
type of writing that just gives directions 
or provides information. We call this 
type of writing, expository writing.  
 
Examples of expository writing are: 
 
 Classroom Rules 
 Textbooks 
 Instructions 
 Book Reports 
 Recipes 
 Flyers 
 Invitations 
 
When explaining how to do something, 
begin with a sentence that tells what 
you will be writing about. Use sequence 
words to help order the steps. End with 
a sentence that tells what was just 
done, but in another way. 
 
 
Basic:  Have students listen to 
examples of expository writing 
from the radio.  Discuss their 
purpose.  Have students 
identify examples of expository 
writing in their environment. 
 
Intermediate:  Provide 
students with excerpts from 
narrative, descriptive and 
expository pieces.  Have them 
identify the expository ones. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write information about their 
school to share with a friend 
who is interested in attending. 
 
 
 
Have students write an 
expository piece.  Use a 
rubric to assess.

Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 90-124 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             160 
 
 
Objective:   3.63 
 Compose an invitation to an event. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Invitations are used to invite someone 
to attend a particular event such as a 
birthday party, wedding, graduation 
etc.  
When composing an invitation, include 
the following:   
 Name of the event  
 Date  
 Time  
 Location/Place  
 
 
 
Basic:  Provide students with a 
template for parents to attend a 
special school assembly.  Have 
them complete the relevant 
information.  
Intermediate:  Ask students to 
identify an event to which they 
would give invitations.  Have 
them answer Who? What? 
Where? When? and Why? 
Advanced:     Have students 
use the information in the 
previous activity to create their 
own invitations for a specific 
event.  Ensure that the required 
information is provided. 
   
 
 
 
Have students create an 
invitation.  Use a rubric to

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             161 
 
Objective:   3.62 
 Write friendly letters. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
Friendly letters are written to provide our 
family and friends information about what is 
happening in our lives. Friendly letters 
should include:  
The Heading - This includes the date. It is 
normally written in the right-hand corner and 
tells when the letter was written.  
Salutation or Greeting - This is the way to 
identify the person to whom you are writing.  
It usually begins with “Dear” and is written 
on the left side of the paper. 
The Body of the Letter – This is considered 
the main part of the letter where you may 
include all of the interesting details about 
your family and friends and write about what 
you have been doing, your hobbies etc.   
The Closing – This is a way of ending the 
letter or signing off.  “Love” and “Your best 
friend” are examples that are used.  The first 
word in the closing is always capitalized.  
Signature – This identifies by name the 
person who is writing the letter. 
 
Basic:  Present students with a 
chart showing a friendly letter.  
Have the names for different 
parts of a friendly letter written 
on small cards.  Using velcro or 
tape, have students place them 
on the correct parts. 
Intermediate:  Have students 
match the parts of a friendly 
letter with their definitions.  
Advanced:   Have students in 
the class write and exchange 
friendly letters. 
 
Have students 
compose a friendly 
letter.  Have them 
use a rubric to 
assess their writing.

Grade 2, 
by:  Kemper, 
Sebranek et al 
p. 48-49,138-
139.

Objective:   3.63 
 Write essays utilizing persuasive techniques. 
Content 
Suggested  
Activities 
Suggested 
Assessment 
Resources 
 
An opinion expresses how a person 
thinks or feels about a particular thing.  
Reasons may be provided as to why 
the person feels that way. 
 
When writing a persuasive paragraph, it 
is important to state how you feel in the 
first sentence.  Add at least three 
sentences with supporting reasons.  Be 
sure to put the most important reasons 
first.  Then close with the final sentence 
restating how you feel. 
 
 
Basic:  Have students share 
about a time when they wanted 
a particular toy or tablet.  Have 
them discuss the reasons they 
gave their parents to purchase 
the item.  Connect this to 
persuasive writing. 
 
Intermediate:  Revisit the story 
of David convincing Saul to 
have him fight Goliath.  Discuss 
the reasons that David gave.  
Connect this to persuasive 
writing. 
 
Advanced:  Have students 
write a paragraph to convince 
their teacher to give them more 
homework. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Have students write a 
persuasive piece.  Use a 
rubric to assess their 
writing.

Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             165 
 
The Reading Block 
 
The Reading Block for lower primary refers to the 90-minute double period dedicated exclusively for the teaching of 
reading.  This daily instructional block encourages the integration of the five components of reading: phonemic 
awareness, phonics, vocabulary, fluency and comprehension.  Within this block, time should be allocated for guided 
reading, where teachers hear students read in small groups as well as individually.   
 
Useful Information about the Teaching of Reading 
 
 
READING LEVELS 
 
 Independent: The highest level at which a child can read with at least a 95% accuracy rate and a 90% 
comprehension rate.  
 
 Instructional: The child can read with an accuracy rate that is between 90% - 94% and can understand the 
information with at least 75% comprehension rate. 
  
 Frustration: The student is reading with less than 90% accuracy and has less than 75% comprehension rate. 
 
 
Basal Readers 
The basal reading approach to reading instruction according to Morin, 2020 is, “…usually a grade-leveled series of 
textbooks...focuses on teaching reading, either by code-emphasis approach (phonetic) or meaning-emphasis approach 
(reading for understanding).”  The basal reading programme provides systematic guidance for teachers using age-
appropriate reading material and includes all aspects of word attack skills, sequential development of word recognition, 
comprehension skills and vocabulary skills.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                         
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             166 
 
Examples of Basal Readers are:  
 Harcourt Trophies 
 Story Town 
 Journey’s 
 Scott Foresman 
 Reading Street 
 
  
The Language Experience Approach 
The Language Experience Approach can be utilized in conjunction with or independent of a basal reading series.  This 
approach can particularly be used to support instruction with struggling readers.  This approach consists of creating an 
experience for students and then discussing the experience with them.  The teacher would record what they have said on 
the board or on chart paper.  Students would then read the story.  This approach provides for an integration of all the 
language arts components (listening, speaking, reading and writing) and helps the children to see relationships: “What I 
can think about, I can talk about. What I can say, I can read. What I can read, I can write.” 
 
 
TYPES OF READING 
 
Guided Reading: 
Guided Reading refers to teachers working with students in small groups to provide support in reading and 
comprehending designated texts.     
 
Oral Reading: 
Suggested Checklist for Oral Reading 
As the teacher listens to and observes the students read orally, the checklist can be used as guide to assess students’ 
oral reading abilities. The students should be given a chance to read the selection silently before they read it orally.  The 
checklist also helps the teacher to determine the students’ specific skill needs.  
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
     
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             167 
 
Sample Checklist for Oral Reading 
1. Determines the mood or tone of the selection (humour, sadness, excitement, suspense, etc.) 
2. Reads in thought phrases or units. 
3. Observes punctuation marks. 
4. Reads smoothly without jerkiness or hesitation. 
5. Uses appropriate volume. 
6. Enunciates clearly and distinctly 
7. Uses a suitable pitch and voice quality. 
8. Is free from strain, tension or nervous habits. 
9. Reads at an appropriate rate so the listeners can understand. 
10. Does not omit, substitute, repeat, or insert words. 
11. Holds the book properly. 
12. Keeps place when reading without difficulty. 
 
SILENT READING 
 
Functional Reading: 
As students progress in their abilities to decode printed symbols, their readings in relation to the content subjects and 
daily living experiences become increasingly important.  The pupil encounters basic texts and supplementary texts in 
Social Studies, Science and Arithmetic, as well as many others.  The more highly specialized the subject matter becomes, 
the more demand for reading skill mastery.  
 
Recreational Reading: 
The reading programme provides for both the development of reading skills and the encouragement of reading for 
pleasure. Recreational reading involves students selecting material to be read for personal satisfaction.  Lifetime interest 
in good books comes from the repeated discovery that reading many kinds of books is satisfying.  To foster recreational 
reading, the teacher must know children’s books, know the students’ ability and interests and be ready to help students 
find the right books at the right time.  Students should be exposed to a wide range of subject matter and the wide 
gradation of difficulty that can be found in library collections.  Teachers should ensure that they maintain interesting 
classroom libraries and encourage students to visit their school libraries. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
                                                 (Ministry of Education Resource Book for Primary Reading Curriculum 1982) 
 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             168 
 
Important Phonics Rules 
  
 
1. The letter ‘c’ has two sounds.  It can be pronounced as /k/ or /s/.  It is pronounced /k/ when it is followed by a, o or 
u as in words like ‘can’, ‘cough’ and ‘cut’.  ‘C’ makes its soft sound /s/ when it is followed by e, i or y as in words 
like ‘cent’, ‘city’ and ‘cycle’. 
 
2. The letter ‘g’ has two sounds.  It can be pronounced as /g/ or /j/.  It makes its hard sound /g/ when it is followed by 
a, o or u as in words like ‘gate’, ‘goat’ or ‘got’.  ‘G’ makes its soft sound /j/ when it is followed by e, i or y as in 
words like ‘gem’, ‘gills’ or ‘gym’.  There are some exceptions to this rule as in words like ‘get’, ‘give’ and ‘gift’. 
 
3. The CVC pattern refers to a syllable that has a consonant followed by a vowel and then another consonant.  When 
this happens, the vowel usually gives its shorts sound.  Examples are words like ‘bed’, ‘man’ and ‘hat’.  
 
4. The Final ‘e’ or CVCE pattern refers to a syllable that has a consonant followed by a vowel, another consonant and 
a final e.  In instances where this occurs, the first vowel gives its long sound (says its name) and the e is silent.  
Examples of words that follow this pattern are ‘made’, ‘hole’, ‘cube’ and ‘date’. 
 
5. The CV pattern refers to words that only have one syllable.  In these two-letter words, the vowel normally gives its 
long sound as in words like ‘go’ and ‘me’.  Some one-syllable words do not follow this pattern as in words like ‘to’ 
and ‘do’. 
 
6. R-Controlled vowels refer to vowels that are followed by the letter ‘r’.  When this happens, the sound of the ‘r’ 
usually dominates the vowel sound, and the sound that the vowel makes is neither a short or a long sound.  Words 
like ‘cart’, ‘far’ and ‘for’ are examples of the r-controlled sounds. 
 
7. When ‘gh’ follows ‘i’, the ‘i’ gives its long sound and the ‘gh’ is silent.  ‘Thigh’ and ‘right’ are examples of this rule. 
 
8. In words that begin with ‘kn’ and ‘wr’, only the sound for the second letter is heard.  In the words ‘knot’ and ‘wreck’ 
the ‘n’ and ‘r’ sounds are heard. 
                                                                                                                                                    Adapted from Language Arts by Gail Tompkins 


Bahamas Ministry of Education – Grade 2 Primary Language Arts Curriculum 2022-2027                                                                                                                             169 
 
Silent Consonants 
 
B:  
The b is silent when followed by the t as in debt, doubt. 
B:  
The b is silent when proceeded by m as in lamb, climb 
C:  
The c is silent in some words, as in scene, muscle

The d is silent in some words in handsome, Wednesday 
Gh:  The gh is usually silent when preceded by a vowel, as in might, thought

The g is silent when it is preceded by n as in gnaw, gnat 
H: 
The h is silent when it is preceded by g as in ghost, ghastly 
H:  
The h is silent in some words as in honour, hour 
K:  
The k is silent when followed by n as in know, knight 
L:  
The l is silent in some words as in talk, should 
N:  
The n is silent when preceded by m as in solemn, column 
P:  
The p is silent when followed by s, as in glimpse 
P:  
The p is silent in some words as in cupboard, receipt 
P:  
The p is silent when followed by n as in pneumonia 
T:  
The t is silent in some words as in listen, often 
W:  
The w is silent when followed by r as in wrong, wrap 
W:  
When wh is followed by o, the w is usually silent as in whole, whose.

170 
 
Vowel Generalizations 
 
The following are some of the most common vowel generalizations. 
 
a. In one syllable words containing two vowel letters (one of which is a final e) the first vowel usually represents a long 
vowel sound, the e is silent. (e.g. kite, bite). 
b. In a one-syllable word that ends with a vowel, the vowel that follows the consonant is usually long (e.g. he, go – 
open syllable). 
c. A vowel is usually short when it appears between two consonants in a one-syllable word (e.g. hat, fox, dig – closed 
syllable). 
d. When i is followed by gh, nd,  or ld, the i usually represents its long sound (e.g. find, child, light). 
e. The vowel o followed by –ld usually has a long sound (e.g. old).  
f. If the only vowel in a word or syllable is an a followed by w, ll and u, the sound of the a is usually that of a short o 
(e.g. wall).  
g. When two vowels appear together in a word, the first vowel usually gives its long sound and the vowel that follows 
is silent. This rule is usually consistent with ai, oa, ee and ay combinations. 
h. Each vowel letter may represent the soft schwa sound often heard in the unaccented syllable (e.g. disappear, 
telegram). 
Y functions as a vowel when it concludes words of more than one syllable (e.g. dad/dy) and it follows a vowel (e.g.)

Blends: bl, cl, fl, gl, pl, sl, br, cr, dr, fr,gr, pr, tr, st, sc, sk, sm, sn, sp, sq, str, dw, sw, tw, spl, spr, chr, sch, scr, shr, thr 
Digraphs: ch, gh, ph, sh, th, wh, qu, -ck,-ng, -ght                        Silent Consonant Pairs: gh, gn, kn, ps, wr, -mb

Commonly Mispronounced Words and Grammar/Usage Errors 
 
 
1. Film  
    one syllable word; one vowel = “film” not “fil/um” 
2. Our     
    pronounced /ow/er; two syllables = “our” not “are” 
3. hour  
    pronounced /ow/er; h is silent = “hour” not “are” 
4. oil 
 
    pronounced /oy/l ; not “earl” 
5. kettle  
    pronounced short e; not “kattle” – This word contains ‘et’, so the ‘e’ is short.  
6. stamp 
    pronounced with a short ‘a’ sound as in “tam”; “stamp”, not “stump” 
7. mine  
    possessive; no ‘s’ is to be added; not “mines” 
8. Thompson     pronounced “Tompson” not “Thompson” - The h is silent. 
9. Furniture 
    this word is a collective noun, therefore -s should not be attached = furniture not furnitures 
     10. often  
    pronounced “oftn” - The ‘t’ and ‘e’ are silent in this word. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
    
 
                                                                                                                         (Ministry of Education Resource Book for Primary Reading Curriculum 1982)

Writing Instruction 
 
Daily Written Composition 
The timetable for the Lower Primary Grades provides daily periods for Written Composition instruction with a total of five 
(5) periods weekly.  In some instances, a daily allotment of 30 minutes for written composition may not be feasible; hence, 
the time allotment for instruction is five periods per week.  According to research and best practices being currently used, 
composition writing should follow a balanced literacy approach.    
 
Instructional Strategy: 10 Day Writing Plan   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
        
The “Ten Day Writing Plan” is a pilot writing model developed to support the daily teaching of written composition. This 
plan can be adapted for use at all primary grades.  It is research based and contains the following components of good 
writing instruction: 
 
· Mentor Texts 
· Enriching Experiences to Build Background Knowledge 
· Vocabulary Building Activities 
· The Writing Process 
· Writing Instructional Strategies 
- Modelled Writing 
- Interactive Writing 
 
The W.A.V.E is an acronym that is used to indicate what should be included a good piece of writing.  The letters refer to: 
Wonderful Introduction 
Add a Topic Sentence 
Very Specific Details 
Exciting Ending

General Accommodations and Modifications for Students with Academic Difficulties 
 
The purpose of implementing accommodations is to ensure equal access to the full school experience for students with 
learning disabilities or difficulties.  Accommodations are usually created for individual students after formal or informal 
assessments have been completed.  
   
ENVIRONMENT 
INSTRUCTION 
AIDS TO ASSIST WITH ASSESSMENT  
 
 Use larger print. 
 Utilize flexible scheduling.  
 Calculator 
 Place fewer items per page. 
 Employ time managing tools like 
a timer. 
 Speech-to-text Software 
 Use visual prompts or cues (for 
example an arrow pointing on a 
page). 
 Provide opportunities for 
retelling as soon as possible 
after a lesson. 
 Text-to-speech 
 Highlight texts. 
 Have students put new learning 
into their own words as soon as 
possible after class discussions.  
 Electronic dictionary 
 Provide alternative answer 
sheets. 
 Utilize graph paper to organize 
Math problems. 
 Spell checker 
 Present information (facts and 
definitions) in songs or poem. 
 Encourage visualization. 
 Grammar checker 
 Provide opportunities for 
individual or small group work. 
 Provide photo copied notes. 
 Live scribe pen 
 Reduce visual and/or auditory 
distractions.  It may be 
necessary to separate desks or 
change location within the 
classroom. 
 Modify assignments as 
necessary. 
 Response choices emphasized

MATHEMATICS
Compiled in 2024 by The Innovation Unit


iv 
 The Bahamas Primary School Mathematics Curriculum 2022-2027 
 
 
 
The Bahamas Primary Mathematics Curriculum focuses on fundamental mathematics concepts and skills, as well as on making connections between related mathematics concepts, 
between mathematics and other disciplines, and between mathematics and everyday life. It also supports new learning about mathematical modelling and financial literacy. 
Additionally, this curriculum is designed to help students build confidence in approaching mathematics and acquire a positive attitude towards the same, learn from their mistakes, 
work collaboratively with others towards a shared goal, value deep thinking and making connections, and become capable and confident mathematics learners. 
 
The curriculum, with varying definitions, is said to be a plan of the teaching-learning process that students of an academic programme are required to undergo. It includes 
objectives and learning outcomes, course contents, teaching methodologies and methods of assessment of learning. Since knowledge in all disciplines and fields is expanding at a 
fast pace and new disciplines are also emerging; it is imperative that curricula be developed and revised accordingly. 
In an effort to remain current with the national mathematics standards, advances in technology and the needs of an ever-evolving society, a timespan of five (5) years has been 
allocated for this document. The period 2022 –  2027 DOES NOT indicate the demise and or extinction of this document, but instead reflects the quinquennial rotation of 
continuous revision, monitoring and assessment of the same. 
The Bahamas Primary Mathematics syllabus has been revised and will be put into effect during the Academic Year (2021 – 2022). The revised syllabus is aligned with the 
rationale and aims of the National Curriculum Framework and is also addressing feedback received on the current syllabus. Below are some changes that are prominent in the 
revised version:  
 
 Inclusion of the Ministry of Education vision, mission and belief statements; 
 Addition of Profile of the Ideal Graduate; 
 Moving from six mathematical strands to five strands as prescribed by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics; 
 Insertion of various topics for a better flow of teaching the subject; 
 Alignment of topics in the Pacing Guide with the strands and objectives; and 
 Placement of number of weeks/ periods and time allocation on the Pacing Guide. 
 
It is hoped that this curriculum document, prepared by the Curriculum Team, will serve the purpose of meeting our national, social and economic needs, and it would also provide 
the level of competency specified in the Department of Education’s Framework to make it compatible with international educational standards.
